children.value:
<div class="note">
 
If you work with JavaScript, or you've ever interacted with a JavaScript project, Node.js or a frontend project, you surely met the `package.json` file.
What's that for? What should you know about it, and what are some of the cool things you can do with it?
file is kind of a manifest for your project. It can do a lot of things, completely unrelated. It's a central repository of configuration for tools, for example. It's also where
store the names and versions for all the installed packages.
Copy
It's empty! There are no fixed requirements of what should be in a
file, for an application. The only requirement is that it respects the JSON format, otherwise it cannot be read by programs that try to access its properties programmatically.
If you're building a Node.js package that you want to distribute over
things change radically, and you must have a set of properties that will help other people use it. We'll see more about this later on.
Copy
property, which tells the name of the app, or package, that's contained in the same folder where this file lives.
Here's a much more complex example, which was extracted from a sample Vue.js application:
Copy

{
    "name": "test-project",
    "version": "1.0.0",
    "description": "A Vue.js project",
    "main": "src/main.js",
    "private": true,
    "scripts": {
        "dev": "webpack-dev-server --inline --progress --config build/webpack.dev.conf.js",
        "start": "npm run dev",
        "unit": "jest --config test/unit/jest.conf.js --coverage",
        "test": "npm run unit",
        "lint": "eslint --ext .js,.vue src test/unit",
        "build": "node build/build.js"
    },
    "dependencies": {
        "vue": "^2.5.2"
    },
    "devDependencies": {
        "autoprefixer": "^7.1.2",
        "babel-core": "^6.22.1",
        "babel-eslint": "^8.2.1",
        "babel-helper-vue-jsx-merge-props": "^2.0.3",
        "babel-jest": "^21.0.2",
        "babel-loader": "^7.1.1",
        "babel-plugin-dynamic-import-node": "^1.2.0",
        "babel-plugin-syntax-jsx": "^6.18.0",
        "babel-plugin-transform-es2015-modules-commonjs": "^6.26.0",
        "babel-plugin-transform-runtime": "^6.22.0",
        "babel-plugin-transform-vue-jsx": "^3.5.0",
        "babel-preset-env": "^1.3.2",
        "babel-preset-stage-2": "^6.22.0",
        "chalk": "^2.0.1",
        "copy-webpack-plugin": "^4.0.1",
        "css-loader": "^0.28.0",
        "eslint": "^4.15.0",
        "eslint-config-airbnb-base": "^11.3.0",
        "eslint-friendly-formatter": "^3.0.0",
        "eslint-import-resolver-webpack": "^0.8.3",
        "eslint-loader": "^1.7.1",
        "eslint-plugin-import": "^2.7.0",
        "eslint-plugin-vue": "^4.0.0",
        "extract-text-webpack-plugin": "^3.0.0",
        "file-loader": "^1.1.4",
        "friendly-errors-webpack-plugin": "^1.6.1",
        "html-webpack-plugin": "^2.30.1",
        "jest": "^22.0.4",
        "jest-serializer-vue": "^0.3.0",
        "node-notifier": "^5.1.2",
        "optimize-css-assets-webpack-plugin": "^3.2.0",
        "ora": "^1.2.0",
        "portfinder": "^1.0.13",
        "postcss-import": "^11.0.0",
        "postcss-loader": "^2.0.8",
        "postcss-url": "^7.2.1",
        "rimraf": "^2.6.0",
        "semver": "^5.3.0",
        "shelljs": "^0.7.6",
        "uglifyjs-webpack-plugin": "^1.1.1",
        "url-loader": "^0.5.8",
        "vue-jest": "^1.0.2",
        "vue-loader": "^13.3.0",
        "vue-style-loader": "^3.0.1",
        "vue-template-compiler": "^2.5.2",
        "webpack": "^3.6.0",
        "webpack-bundle-analyzer": "^2.9.0",
        "webpack-dev-server": "^2.9.1",
        "webpack-merge": "^4.1.0"
    },
    "engines": {
        "node": ">= 6.0.0",
        "npm": ">= 3.0.0"
    },
    "browserslist": ["> 1%", "last 2 versions", "not ie <= 8"]
}
is a brief description of the app/package
set the entry point for the application
prevents the app/package to be accidentally published on
defines a set of node scripts you can run
sets which versions of Node.js this package/app works on
is used to tell which browsers (and their versions) you want to support
All those properties are used by either
or other tools that we can use.
This section describes the properties you can use in detail. We refer to "package" but the same thing applies to local applications which you do not use as packages.
Most of those properties are only used on
, others by scripts that interact with your code, like
Copy
The name must be less than 214 characters, must not have spaces, it can only contain lowercase letters, hyphens (
This is because when a package is published on
, it gets its own URL based on this property.
If you published this package publicly on GitHub, a good value for this property is the GitHub repository name.
Copy
Can also be used with this format:
Copy
As well as the author, the project can have one or more contributors. This property is an array that lists them.
Copy
Can also be used with this format:
Copy
Links to the package issue tracker, most likely a GitHub issues page
Copy
Copy
Indicates the current version of the package.
Copy
This property follows the semantic versioning (semver) notation for versions, which means the version is always expressed with 3 numbers:
The first number is the major version, the second the minor version and the third is the patch version.

There is a meaning in these numbers: a release that only fixes bugs is a patch release, a release that introduces backward-compatible changes is a minor release, a major release can have breaking changes.
Indicates the license of the package.
Copy
This property contains an array of keywords that associate with what your package does.
Copy
This helps people find your package when navigating similar packages, or when browsing the
This property contains a brief description of the package
Copy
"description": "A package to work with strings"
This is especially useful if you decide to publish your package to
so that people can find out what the package is about.
This property specifies where this package repository is located.
Copy
prefix. There are other popular services baked in:
Copy
Copy
You can explicitly set the version control system:
Copy
You can use different version control systems:
Copy
Sets the entry point for the package.
When you import this package in an application, that's where the application will search for the module exports.
Copy
prevents the app/package to be accidentally published on
Copy
Defines a set of node scripts you can run
Copy

"scripts": {
  "dev": "webpack-dev-server --inline --progress --config build/webpack.dev.conf.js",
  "start": "npm run dev",
  "unit": "jest --config test/unit/jest.conf.js --coverage",
  "test": "npm run unit",
  "lint": "eslint --ext .js,.vue src test/unit",
  "build": "node build/build.js"
}
These scripts are command line applications. You can run them by calling
You can use any name you want for a command, and scripts can do literally anything you want.
When you install a package using npm or yarn:
Copy

npm install <PACKAGENAME>
yarn add <PACKAGENAME>
that package is automatically inserted in this list.
Copy
because they are meant to be installed only on a development machine, not needed to run the code in production.
When you install a package using npm or yarn:
Copy

npm install --save-dev <PACKAGENAME>
yarn add --dev <PACKAGENAME>
that package is automatically inserted in this list.
Copy
Sets which versions of Node.js and other commands this package/app work on
Copy

Is used to tell which browsers (and their versions) you want to support. It's referenced by Babel, Autoprefixer, and other tools, to only add the polyfills and fallbacks needed to the browsers you target.
Copy
This configuration means you want to support the last 2 major versions of all browsers with at least 1% of usage (from the
file can also host command-specific configuration, for example for Babel, ESLint, and more.
Each has a specific property, like
and others. Those are command-specific, and you can find how to use those in the respective command/project documentation.
You have seen in the description above version numbers like these:
. What do they mean, and which other version specifiers can you use?
That symbol specifies which updates your package accepts, from that dependency.
Given that using semver (semantic versioning) all versions have 3 digits, the first being the major release, the second the minor release and the third is the patch release, you have these "
You can combine most of the versions in ranges, like this:
, to either use 1.0.0 or one release from 1.1.0 up, but lower than 1.2.0.
What's that? You probably know about the
file, which is much more common and has been around for much longer.
The goal of the file is to keep track of the exact version of every package that is installed so that a product is 100% reproducible in the same way even if packages are updated by their maintainers.
This solves a very specific problem that
left unsolved. In package.json you can set which versions you want to upgrade to (patch or minor), using the
, you want to only update patch releases:
, you want to update patch and minor releases:
, that is the exact version that will be used, always
You don't commit to Git your node_modules folder, which is generally huge, and when you try to replicate the project on another machine by using the
syntax and a patch release of a package has been released, that one is going to be installed. Same for
If you specify exact versions, like
in the example, you are not affected by this problem.
It could be you, or another person trying to initialize the project on the other side of the world by running

So your original project and the newly initialized project are actually different. Even if a patch or minor release should not introduce breaking changes, we all know bugs can (and so, they will) slide in.
sets your currently installed version of each package
will use those exact versions when running
This concept is not new, and other programming languages package managers (like Composer in PHP) use a similar system for years.
file needs to be committed to your Git repository, so it can be fetched by other people, if the project is public or you have collaborators, or if you use Git as a source for deployments.
The dependencies versions will be updated in the
This is an example structure of a
file we get when we run
Copy

{
  "requires": true,
  "lockfileVersion": 1,
  "dependencies": {
    "ansi-regex": {
      "version": "3.0.0",
      "resolved": "https://registry.npmjs.org/ansi-regex/-/ansi-regex-3.
0.0.tgz",
      "integrity": "sha1-7QMXwyIGT3lGbAKWa922Bas32Zg="
    },
    "cowsay": {

,
      "integrity": "sha512-3PVFe6FePVtPj1HTeLin9v8WyLl+VmM1l1H/5P+BTTDkM
Ajufp+0F9eLjzRnOHzVAYeIYFF5po5NjRrgefnRMQ==",

        "optimist": "~0.6.1",
        "string-width": "~2.1.1",
        "strip-eof": "^1.0.0"
      }
    },
    "get-stdin": {
      "version": "5.0.1",

1.tgz",
      "integrity": "sha1-Ei4WFZHiH/TFJTAwVpPyDmOTo5g="
    },
    "is-fullwidth-code-point": {
      "version": "2.0.0",

is-fullwidth-code-point-2.0.0.tgz",
      "integrity": "sha1-o7MKXE8ZkYMWeqq5O+764937ZU8="
    },
    "minimist": {

.tgz",

    "optimist": {

In turn, those packages require other packages, as we can see from the
They are added in alphabetical order into the file, and each one has a
field that points to the package location, and an
string that we can use to verify the package.
